--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ashot Petrosian" <ashot@m...> wrote:
> On Sun, 17 Jul 2005 23:22:30 -0500, Joseph Reisinger 
<joeraii@c...> wrote:
> >>
> >> Yea, this was the first thing that hit me when I read about 
NEAT..
> >> Is there an anti-modular contingency? If there is, we'll 
show 'em ;)
> >
> > I wouldn't say everyone is anti-modular, they just seem focused 
more
> > on issues with the standard NEAT implementation, which just by 
itself
> > has quite a lot of issues :) Though to be fair both Ken and I 
have
> > come to the conclusion that the ad-hoc kind of modularity 
present in
> > e.g. mNEAT is kind of the wrong way to approach the problem. 
Thats
> > not to say doing work in the area is not extremely valuable (and 
may
> > yield some excellent results), its just that there might be 
other,
> > better ways of doing modularity besides explicit modularization. 
Ken
> > and I wrote a position statement that appeared in a GECCO 
workshop on
> > modularity last year that focuses on this topic. If you haven't
> > already, I'd say it might be worth reading. Its available here:
> >
> > http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04ws
> 
> So does this mean someone is working on a NEAT with indirect 
encoding?
> 

I know of at least 1 case where someone already built NEAT with an 
indirect encoding, but they scrapped the design because they didn't 
like the encoding they chose.  One recent Ph.D. grad in Norway, 
Diego Federici, has taken some of the principles of NEAT and applied 
them to an indirect encoding.  His web site is here:

www.idi.ntnu.no/~federici/ 

In any case, I'd say a fair number of people are thinking about 
indirect NEAT at this point.  One of the main reasons for this is 
our 2003 paper, "A Taxonomy for Artificial Embryogeny," which was a 
large review exploring this issue:

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:alife03

If you haven't read it, you may find this article interesting since 
it explores the problem with a biological perspective, addressing 
some your comments below about whether such a system is possible.  
You may be surprised that numerous developmental encodings have 
already been developed and successfully utilized to evolve things 
from robot morphoologies to sorting networks.

I thought the discussion of the word "ad-hoc" was also interesting.  
I'd actually say the word can be used in several different ways.  In 
one sense, the engineer is analytic while nature is ad-hoc.  
However, ad-hoc design of this type is incredibly powerful, whereas 
design based on analytic common sense breaks down at extreme levels 
of complexity.  For example, the way nature builds things it might 
turn a refigerator into a TV instead of just breaking the problem of 
building a TV into parts and putting them together bit by bit.  
That's pretty ad-hoc as far as ad-hoc goes  (after all, why go 
through a refigerator?), but it's also ingenious in a way an 
engineer would never be.

On the other hand, the idea of arbitrarily picking a component of a 
system and duplicating it all over the place is totally ad-hoc and 
extremely brittle.  That doesn't mean that duplication of genetic 
sequences cannot be quite powerful, but that's different from an 
engineer taking a chunk of your machine and praying that it will 
work in another part.  You might point out that engineers don't 
really do that- they don't just randomly take parts and duplicate 
them without considering the application.  But that's precisely the 
point: Nature is not an engineer so why would you expect it to work 
like one?

It's way too early to discount the power of developmental encodings.
On the other hand, it's also too early to endorse them.  They seem 
to have great potential but I'd keep an open mind at this early 
stage in the field.

ken
